moves.1. e4: A nice game, resulting in an interesting finale which finished draw.
moves.3... exd4 4. Nxd4 Nxd4 5. Qxd4 Nf6 6. Nc: White advances his pawns, their structure is vulnerable, but they capture space...
moves.8... Qd7 9. Bg5 Be7 10. O-O-O O-O: O-O, with the plan to attack against the enemy castle (a bit risky, since white has his pawns advanced in this side)
moves.11. Bxf6 Bxf6 12. Qd3 b5:
After the changes, black begins his attack, since the open centre gives his bishops great power.

However, black didn't notice the pawn is lost...
moves.13. Qxb5 Qxb5: ... Exchanging Queens might not seem the best idea (since it reduces his attack capabilities)
moves.14. Bxb5: Perhaps better was Nxb5, with more threats, although the bishop move develops one more piece, and doesn't open the space for the black bishops...
moves.14... Bxc3: Black sees that he can take his pawn back, by exchanging one bishop for the knight... Loses the advantage of the 2 bishops, but material is even again, and black has perhaps a bit better pawn structure
moves.15. bxc3 Bxa2 16. Kd2: Trying to get the king in the game?
moves.18. f5 gxf5 19. exf5 Bd5: white seems to have an advantage in the one side, although most of his  pieces are not there. Black has clearly more power in the other, but his pawns are not at all advanced,
moves.20. Rhg1 a6 21. Ba4 a5: Each one tries to attack in his strong side
moves.22... Bc6: Rejects, so that the he keeps the pawn advantage in the side, although this adds pressure to f7, and generally the black king's side.
moves.24. Ba2 Kg7: Unforking f7, cause it may be needed soon. Black king gets a bit more active
moves.25. Re7: Rook is on the 7nth line, more pressure for the black.
moves.25... Ra7 26. g5: White seems to have some good chances here...
moves.26... d5: reducing the pressure on the black king side
moves.30. Rf1+ Kg7 31. Re7+: Things don't seem so relaxing for the black, although the pawns have gone now...
moves.31... Kg8 32. Rxf8+: White exchanges one rook, although these 2 were his biggest advantage in this side.
moves.32... Kxf8 33. Re6: Threatens the bishop, and g6. If 33 ... B38, then it is Bxd5
moves.33... Bd7: Prefers to exchange the side pawns, so there is no more danger from this side (he has an advantage on the other, even after d5 is gone)
moves.34. Rxg6 Bxh3 35. Bxd5 Ke7: Trying to get the king into the game, and also avoid any rook threats
moves.36. Rh6: Doesn't seem to have a real point there...
moves.38. Rh7+ Kd6 39. Rh6+ Kc5 40. Rh5+ Kb6: White tries to check and then get an unguarded piece are correctly defended. Rooks exchange inevitable, if white decides so.
moves.42. Kc1: Getting his king in a better solution... Shows that 16 Kd2 was not so good...
moves.42... a3: Keep advancing and keeping white king away from b2
moves.47... a2: Grants his king a better position
(If i recall correctly, black offered a draw here, but white refused)
moves.53. Kb2 Ka4 54. Kc2: White decides to avoid a draw and go for the win.
moves.54... Ka3 55. Kd2 Kb2 56. Kd3 Kb3 57. Kd: Black gets a pawn. Material is even, but black king is a bit better positioned
moves.58... Kd5 59. Kd3 Kd6 60. c4: Black hadn't thought of this move, thought he would be winning by  Kc4
moves.60... Kd7 61. Ke4 Ke6 62. Kf4 Kf6 63. Ke: Draw offer accepted, since both players knew how to keep their positions...
